This is an incredible read.
"I think Microsoft Game Studios has moved on, and they don't have anyone there who manages their history and back-catalog in matters like these. If for some reason, my last contact finds the opportunity and gets back to me, I would gladly spend my weekends putting together an update, but I'm no longer going to actively pursue it. I've searched for that person who could tell me yeah or nay for over a year but he (or she) is not to be found."
Really sad after reading this. But also excited because the interest is back. This was written 7 years back and who would have thought things will change? Nobody! A game which started development work in 1995 is being discussed and played by loads of people across the globe in 2017. Matt Pritchard. You should be a proud man. I really hope you actually know about it.

trivia: 20 years back when the game was first designed, the first working version was called "Dawn of Man" by Goodman and his team.
Source: Gamasutra.

excerpt from Hiddenpath.com
Mark was a lead designer, designer, and programmer on titles in the Age of Empires franchise and held the lead designer position on the best-selling strategy game of all-time: Age of Empires 2: Age of Kings. The titles Mark contributed to have sold over 17 million copies worldwide. Mark has lent his expertise towards aiding other game developers working on Xbox through his role as a Technical Game Manager for the Xbox organization and supporting game developers around the world.
Mark's expertise and passion have not only made him a remarkable asset to HPE, they have also allowed him to share his knowledge worldwide. Mark has written papers on multiplayer networking, game design, and usability. He has given dozens of insightful and critically acclaimed presentations at universities, conferences and events on five continents (he says he is just waiting for South America and Antarctica to call). Mark has been a panel leader for the Academy of Interactive Arts Sciences Academy Awards Nomination group, has served on the Austin Games Conference advisory board, and worked with International Game Developer Association special interest groups.

WRITING.TITLE: How far ahead do you wall?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hi Guys,
How far do you wall when you play defensive or even mix-strategy games? Options below, add yours. [Map - Arabia]
1) Initially make a compact wall with palisade and later in the game add stone walls ahead of it.
2) Wait for late Feudal and start stone walling, don't make any palisade walls.
3) Wall half the map [based on mini map learning] right away as you hit Feudal age. Few expert players play this game at times.
4) Only make short box/triangle walls throughout the game protecting villagers and resources.

No, no, it's not a thing certainly. But it's a conscious choice.
Reasons being, in a highly competitive game, when you are slinging possibly one player, you can sustain his army production with around 150 villagers. You would hardly (probably never) see an expert Slinger (Slam?) make 200 villagers [if he is not doing caravans].
Also, there are games, where you see the Slinger has stopped villager production, because he is slinging in a very competitive battle where if he stops due to food being consumed for his villager production, the slingee can lose the battle and that can decide the faith of the game. :-)
Slinging requires proper planning, so it's ideal with team-mates/clan members/people you play regularly.
Thanks.

Adding to what Urc0mp already mentioned.
You can choose to Sling in Feudal Age or even Castle Age. After a certain point, you stop producing villagers and just produce good economy to support your team-mate/s. Remember, you need to continuously sling, don't let any of your resources cross 300!

WRITING.TITLE: Uno-Rage: Can you win a game with just one kind of Unit?
WRITING.TEXT:
Hello People, hope you are doing good.
Have you guys played a game with a human opponent [Maybe you have done it with the hard/hardest AI] with just one kind of mobile unit?
We are playing a few games with this style, it is actually fun.
1) If you have made one Archer, you ll have to make only Archer/Crossbow/Arbalest...you cannot make Castle Archer units, you cannot make Skirms. No siege is allowed. You need to beat the opponent [make him resign] with just Archers. Mind you he can't really make Skirms, he can't possibly win with only Skirms. Chu-ko-nus is the best bet to win with Archers I guess. Heavy Cavalry Archers?
2) Cavalry line [Only with Scout/Light Cav/Hussar], or [Only with Knight/Hussar/Pala]. Pala is the best bet, can't really win with Camels! Imperial Camels?
3) Only with Mango/Onagers/Siege Ona or only Scorpions/Heavy Scorps [Daut game anybody?] or maybe even only Trebs (katapur] with Japanese [Fun?]
4) Only with Castle units, only with Petards? :-)
I have played a few games with hard AI, it's a bit easy, but this will be a very difficult thing against human opponents.
Why don't you guys try? Which Unit will you choose?
Note: The first scout is obviously not counted in this. You can make towers too but that is not considered as a Mobile Unit.
